ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the background and people behind economic ideas
Learnt about a range of economists and important economic ideas. Also learnt in depth about one specific chosen idea and economist.
I learned that economics goes beyond finance and macroeconomics. I acquired knowledge about many different areas of economics and a deeper understanding of social sciences as a whole.

We learned about economists from throughout the centuries that were deserving of a nobel prize, regardless of if they got one. We also learned how to analyze economic ideas in perspective of the modern day.
I learned that economics is a very diverse field and is made up of various areas such as psychology and mathematics. It is more than just a study about how to make profits.
Some basic economic theory fundementals
An overview of key economic ideas

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Espin-Sanchez is super accommodating (maybe too accommodating lol), and the workload is extremely light. However, the online lectures become harder to engage with as the semester progresses because they're all in the same format and don't include much discussion of current events. Would probably be more engaging in person, though!

The course was very interesting and the weekly readings were short and to the point. There was very little opportunity to engage in the classes as they seminar felt more like a lecture than a discussion.
Prof was great. He was kind, funny, and wants you to succeed.
Very easy class with interesting points. It depends on what you are interested in, so there will be weeks with interesting lectures but others can be quite boring.
Great structure and content. Only thing - I think would be better in person, as there wasnt as many opportunities for student input and discussions as I had hoped for.

I would say that I would have liked to have more room to interact and to express my opinions, since the class felt sometimes more like a lecture than a seminar. Otherwise, the instructor was affable and attentive to students needs.
The course was very good and interesting. The professor was very knowledgeable and fun. It could be improved if taught in person obviously.

Strength: I think the course was well taught the ideas were broken down into very simple lectures that were easy to follow with relatable examples. 

Weakness: Perhaps it was because of the online format but there was very little student led discussion.

Strength - well-organized classes, Professor Espin-Sanchez paid a lot of attention to explaining complex ideas in a simple way and provided lots of useful/interesting examples 
Weakness - would be great if there can be more discussion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe mix up the lecture format / include videos and discussion about current events.
More discussion
I think it fell to the classic pitfall of covid which is being unable to focus on powerpoints. This will hopefully be better in the future.
Perhaps more opportunities for students to actively engage with the content.
Meeting in small groups outside, if everyone was on campus, would have been an improvement. Or some form of meet up for people in New Haven.

I think the lecture slides being uploaded was very useful and the articles were very informative and well written. Having easy access to them during lecture made things a bit easier. The online quizzes given every week also helped consolidate the information learned.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're looking for a gut social science / intro to some basic econ. But there are probably more interesting classes to take, especially among freshman seminars.
Yes, if you are an economics major you should take this class as it helps you understand the concepts taught in other econ classes better
Yes!! I loved the idea and structure of the course, and found it very interesting.
I would not necessarily recommend this course as a seminar. Otherwise, yes, its a good introduction to social sciences.
Absolutely! The class and professor were fantastic and I can only imagine how much better it would be in a normal year.

I would. It is not a traditional economics class. There is a lot of overlap with other discipline areas and I think it gives a broad overview of past and current developments in the economic field. Be warned that the final paper can become a problem if you don't start it on time!
For students who are interested in economics but not very committed yet.
Yes, a great class!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live seminar
Virtual seminar
No
n/a
